mcq.question: A new BOP control system is being designed. Who should be involved in defining requirements?

options.A: Engineers only—they understand the technical specs
options.B: Drillers, assistant drillers, and tool pushers—the end users

mcq.explanation: End users understand operational reality. Their input ensures the system design matches actual task requirements and constraints.

hfo-m1-l3.title: Installation Design and Layout
hfo-m1-l3.content: Equipment layout affects accessibility for operation, inspection, and maintenance. Valves, gauges, and controls must be reachable, visible, and logically arranged. Poor layout increases error rates, slows emergency response, and creates hazards. Apply ergonomic standards during design—retrofits are costly.
questions: What equipment on your rig is difficult to access or operate safely?
How do layout issues affect maintenance or emergency procedures?

hfo-m1-l4.title: Design Verification and Commissioning
hfo-m1-l4.content: HF objectives specified during design must be verified during construction and commissioning. Walk-throughs, mock-ups, and usability testing catch design compromises before operations begin. Verify that valves, panels, and escape routes meet HF specifications. Don't assume design intent survived construction.
questions: How does your organization verify HF requirements during commissioning?
What design intent has been compromised during construction on projects you've seen?
hfo-m1-l4.scenario: During commissioning, you discover critical valves are blocked by newly installed piping. The design drawings show clear access. What went wrong with the HF integration process?

hfo-m2-l1.title: Drilling Control Room (Doghouse) Design
hfo-m2-l1.content: The driller's cabin contains well control instrumentation critical for safe intervention. Displays must be visible, controls accessible, and information layout logical. High cognitive load during well control events demands optimal HMI design. Apply ISO 11064 standards and involve drillers in layout decisions.
questions: Can the driller see all critical parameters without head movement or obstruction?
How well does the doghouse layout support high-stress decision-making?

hfo-m2-l2.title: Marine Control Room Design
hfo-m2-l2.content: Marine control rooms manage DP systems, ballast, fire and gas detection, and communications. Watch-keeping demands sustained vigilance. Control room design must support situational awareness, minimize fatigue, and enable rapid emergency response. Lighting, noise, and workspace ergonomics all affect performance.
questions: Does your marine control room design support 12-hour watch-keeping without excessive fatigue?
What environmental factors (noise, lighting, temperature) affect marine crew performance?

mcq.question: A DP operator monitors six screens during a critical operation. Two alarms activate simultaneously on different screens. What HMI issue is this?

options.A: Operator error—should have been more attentive
options.B: Poor information integration—critical alarms should be centralized

mcq.explanation: Spreading critical information across multiple displays increases cognitive load and slows response. Alarm integration principles require prioritization and centralization.

hfo-m2-l3.title: Human-Machine Interface Standards
hfo-m2-l3.content: HMI design affects error rates and response times. Controls should map intuitively to system function. Displays should prioritize critical information and minimize clutter. Follow EEMUA 201 and ASM Consortium guidelines. Inconsistent HMI design across systems creates negative transfer and increases errors.
questions: Are HMI designs standardized across your rig's control systems?
When have you operated a control where the interface behaved opposite to your expectation?

hfo-m2-l4.title: Alarm Management in Drilling Operations
hfo-m2-l4.content: Effective alarm systems alert operators to abnormal conditions requiring action. Too many alarms cause alarm fatigue—operators ignore or silence them. Follow EEMUA 191 and IADC drilling alarm guidelines: prioritize alarms, eliminate nuisance alarms, and ensure each alarm is actionable. Poor alarm management has contributed to major incidents.
questions: How many alarms does your drilling or marine control room receive per hour?
What percentage of those alarms are false, nuisance, or informational rather than actionable?
hfo-m2-l4.scenario: During a well control event, 47 alarms activate within 90 seconds. The driller acknowledges and silences most of them to focus on well parameters. What alarm management failure occurred?

hfo-m3-l1.title: Human Reliability Analysis for Drilling
hfo-m3-l1.content: Human Reliability Analysis (HRA) identifies where human actions are critical to preventing or mitigating Major Accident Hazards (MAH). It quantifies the likelihood of human failure and identifies Performance Influencing Factors (PIFs). HRA should be integrated into safety case risk assessments for safety-critical tasks.
questions: Has HRA been performed for your rig's safety-critical tasks?
What tasks on your rig have the highest consequence if performed incorrectly?

hfo-m3-l2.title: Performance Influencing Factors
hfo-m3-l2.content: PIFs are conditions that affect human reliability: competence, time pressure, fatigue, procedure quality, equipment design, and organizational culture. Identifying and optimizing PIFs reduces error likelihood. Poor PIFs make even skilled operators unreliable. Good PIFs enable consistent performance.
questions: What PIFs most frequently degrade performance on your rig?
How does your organization assess and improve PIFs for safety-critical tasks?

mcq.question: A well control procedure is rarely used. The driller is fatigued after 11 hours on shift. The BOP panel has inconsistent labeling. How many negative PIFs exist?

options.A: One—fatigue is the only real issue
options.B: Two—fatigue and procedure familiarity
options.C: Three—infrequent task, fatigue, and poor HMI design

mcq.explanation: All three are PIFs: task infrequency (lack of practice), fatigue (reduced cognitive performance), and poor labeling (increased error likelihood). They compound risk.

hfo-m3-l3.title: Bowtie Analysis and Barrier Management
hfo-m3-l3.content: Bowtie diagrams map threats, top events, and consequences with barriers that prevent or mitigate. Human actions can be threats (initiating events) or escalation factors (barrier failures). Effective barrier management ensures barriers are in place, functional, and regularly tested. Human reliability is critical to barrier effectiveness.
questions: Does your safety case use bowtie analysis to illustrate MAH control?
Where do human actions appear as critical barriers in your MAH scenarios?

hfo-m3-l4.title: Human Factors in MAH Scenarios
hfo-m3-l4.content: Human actions can prevent, initiate, detect, or mitigate major accidents. Safety cases must demonstrate how human performance variability is managed. This includes task analysis, error identification, and control measures proportionate to risk. Work-as-done often differs from work-as-imagined—understand actual practice, not just procedures.
questions: What workarounds or informal practices exist for safety-critical tasks on your rig?
How does your organization reconcile procedures with operational reality?
hfo-m3-l4.scenario: A safety case assumes a two-person verification for BOP function tests. In practice, one person performs the test while the second signs off remotely. What HF issue exists in the safety case?

hfo-m4-l1.title: 21-Day Rotations and Tour Extensions
hfo-m4-l1.content: Standard UK offshore tours are 21 consecutive days, 12-hour shifts. This pattern exists due to transport and accommodation constraints. Tour extensions beyond 21 days require OIM authorization and fitness assessment. Extended tours increase fatigue and error risk—balance operational need against human performance limits.
questions: How often are tours extended beyond 21 days on your rig?
What criteria does your OIM use to authorize tour extensions?

hfo-m4-l2.title: 12-Hour Shift Patterns Offshore
hfo-m4-l2.content: Two 12-hour shifts provide better coverage than three 8-hour shifts with fewer personnel offshore. However, 12-hour shifts for 21 consecutive days create significant fatigue. Shift design must account for circadian rhythms, task complexity, and workload peaks. Night shifts are physiologically harder and never fully adapt.
questions: Do you work days or nights? How well do you adapt?
What time of your shift is performance most degraded?

mcq.question: It's day 18 of a 21-day trip, 10 hours into a night shift. A complex non-routine task is required. What should the supervisor consider?

options.A: Assign it—experienced crews can handle it
options.B: Assess if fatigue makes it safer to defer to day shift
options.C: Assign it but with minimal supervision—they know what to do

mcq.explanation: Cumulative fatigue at day 18, compounded by night shift and late in shift, creates high error risk. Deferring non-urgent complex tasks is prudent fatigue management.

hfo-m4-l3.title: Fatigue Risk Management Offshore
hfo-m4-l3.content: Fatigue Risk Management Plans (FRMP) identify fatigue hazards and implement controls. Offshore FRMPs should address tour length, shift patterns, workload, overtime, and rest quality. Monitor fatigue indicators: near-misses, errors, and self-reporting. Offshore fatigue is chronic and cumulative—rest days ashore are essential for recovery.
questions: Does your company have a formal FRMP? What does it include?
How does your organization monitor and respond to fatigue indicators?

hfo-m4-l4.title: Staffing Levels and Multi-Skilling
hfo-m4-l4.content: Adequate staffing ensures safety-critical tasks are reliably performed under normal and abnormal conditions. De-manning without workload reduction increases error risk. Multi-skilling provides flexibility but requires competence verification. Use staffing assessment methods like CRIOP to evaluate whether manning supports MAH control during emergencies.
questions: Have staffing levels changed on your rig? How was safety impact assessed?
What safety-critical tasks rely on multi-skilled personnel? Are they competent in all roles?
hfo-m4-l4.scenario: Staffing is reduced from 3 to 2 personnel per shift in the engine room. Workload remains the same. During an emergency, can two people manage the response that previously required three?

hfo-m5-l1.title: Procedural Integrity for Safety-Critical Tasks
hfo-m5-l1.content: Procedures for safety-critical tasks must be accurate, usable, and followed. Link procedures to MAH scenarios and ensure they reflect operational reality. Involve end users in procedure development and review. Detailed procedures suit infrequent, complex tasks; simple checklists suit routine tasks. Non-compliance often signals poor procedure design.
questions: Are procedures for your safety-critical tasks accurate and usable?
What procedures are routinely bypassed or modified? Why?

hfo-m5-l2.title: Permit-to-Work and Shift Handovers
hfo-m5-l2.content: PTW systems control hazardous work. Major accidents have occurred when permits weren't communicated across shifts or between contractors and operators. Shift handovers transfer situational awareness—face-to-face handovers are better than logs alone. Use structured formats like SBAR. Verify the incoming shift understands active permits and system status.
questions: How are active PTW permits communicated during shift handover?
What information is most often missing or unclear during handovers?

mcq.question: During shift handover, the outgoing supervisor mentions 'a few permits active, nothing major.' What's the problem?

options.A: No problem—permits are logged in the system
options.B: Too vague—incoming supervisor needs specific permit details and hazards
options.D: Incoming supervisor should check the log independently

mcq.explanation: Vague handovers fail to transfer critical situational awareness. Specific permit details, hazards, and work status must be communicated face-to-face.

hfo-m5-l3.title: Safety-Critical Communications
hfo-m5-l3.content: Effective communication is critical during drilling operations, emergencies, and PTW management. Use closed-loop communication for safety-critical instructions. Standard terminology reduces misunderstanding. Communication barriers include noise, language, hierarchy, and remote coordination (rig floor to doghouse). Design communication systems for worst-case conditions.
questions: Does your crew use closed-loop communication for safety-critical tasks?
What communication failures have you witnessed or experienced?

hfo-m5-l4.title: Competence Management for Offshore Roles
hfo-m5-l4.content: Competence Assurance Systems verify individuals can reliably perform safety-critical tasks. Competence standards should link to MAH scenarios and key procedures. Training alone is insufficient—assess practical performance. Manage contractor competence through verification and oversight. Competence degrades without practice—maintain currency for infrequent safety-critical tasks.
questions: How does your organization assess and maintain competence for safety-critical roles?
How is contractor competence verified before permitting safety-critical work?
hfo-m5-l4.scenario: A contractor arrives to perform well control equipment maintenance—a safety-critical task. What evidence of competence should be verified before issuing a permit?

hfo-m5-l5.title: Supervision in Drilling Operations
hfo-m5-l5.content: Front-line supervisors (tool pushers, drillers, barge engineers) are the link between planning and execution. Supervisors allocate work, monitor compliance, manage contractors, and provide leadership. Supervisor competence includes technical skills and non-technical skills: leadership, communication, and performance management. Effective supervision is a critical control for MAH.
questions: What competency standards exist for supervisors on your rig?
How do supervisors balance production pressure against safety-critical compliance?
hfo-m5-l5.scenario: A supervisor observes a crew member skipping a step in a safety-critical procedure to save time. The task completes successfully. What should the supervisor do?

hfo-m6-l1.title: UK Safety Case Regulations Overview
hfo-m6-l1.content: The Offshore Installations (Safety Case) Regulations 2015 require duty holders to demonstrate MAH are managed to a level that is As Low As Reasonably Practicable (ALARP). Safety cases must address human and organizational factors. Inspectors assess HF integration across design, risk assessment, and management systems. Compliance isn't optional—it's regulatory.
questions: Has your organization submitted a safety case under SCR 2015?
How well does your safety case address human factors?

hfo-m6-l2.title: Human Factors in Safety Case Submissions
hfo-m6-l2.content: Safety cases must demonstrate systematic HF consideration across 14 topic areas: HF in design, managing human performance, organizational integrity, and HF in SEMS. Each topic requires evidence proportionate to MAH risk. For heritage rigs, demonstrate what's been done and justify where full compliance is impractical. New builds must meet current standards.
questions: Which of the 14 HF topics are strongest in your safety case? Which are weakest?
For older rigs, how do you justify deviations from current HF standards?

mcq.question: A 20-year-old rig operates in the UKCS. Control room layout doesn't meet ISO 11064. What should the safety case demonstrate?

options.A: Nothing—it's a heritage asset, standards don't apply
options.B: Why full compliance is impractical and what alternative measures are in place
options.C: Plan to retrofit to full compliance immediately
options.D: That the rig operates safely despite non-compliance

mcq.explanation: Safety cases for heritage assets should explain why full compliance is impractical (cost, lifecycle) and demonstrate alternative risk controls that achieve ALARP.

hfo-m6-l3.title: Management of Organizational Change
hfo-m6-l3.content: Organizational changes—staffing, structure, outsourcing, role changes—can degrade MAH control if poorly managed. MOC procedures must assess safety impacts of organizational changes, including transitional risks. Key competencies must be transferred, workload managed, and procedures updated before changes are implemented. Organizational MOC is as critical as technical MOC.
questions: Does your MOC procedure explicitly address organizational changes?
What organizational changes have occurred without adequate HF impact assessment?

hfo-m6-l4.title: Accident Investigation and HF Analysis
hfo-m6-l4.content: Investigations should identify active failures (front-line errors) and latent failures (organizational/system weaknesses). Stopping at 'operator error' is inadequate. Ask why the operator made that error—training, procedures, fatigue, design, supervision? Learning from incidents requires HF analysis. Communicate lessons across the organization and implement systemic improvements.
questions: Do your incident investigations routinely identify latent organizational factors?
How are HF learnings from incidents communicated and implemented?
hfo-m6-l4.scenario: An incident investigation concludes 'driller error caused the event.' The driller was on day 20 of 21, working nights, and the procedure was last revised 8 years ago. What latent factors were missed?

hfo-m6-l5.title: Continuous Improvement and HF Performance
hfo-m6-l5.content: HF performance should be monitored through leading indicators (audits, observations, near-misses) and lagging indicators (incidents, non-conformances). Use performance data to drive continuous improvement. Audit HF elements of SEMS regularly. Engage workforce in identifying HF issues and solutions. Mature HF programs evolve based on operational experience.
questions: What HF performance indicators does your organization track?
How is workforce feedback on HF issues collected and acted upon?
hfo-m6-l5.scenario: Near-miss trends show increasing procedural non-compliance on night shifts. What HF performance indicators should be investigated: fatigue, procedure usability, supervision, or workload?
